he is a fool that destourbeth the moder to wepe in the deth of hire child / til she haue wept hire fille / as for a certeyn tyme /
and thanne shal man don his diligence / with amyable wordes hire to reconforte / and preye hire / of hire wepyng for to stynte /
for which reson / this noble wyf Prudence / suffred hire housbond for to wepe and crye / as for a certeyn space /
And whan she say hire tyme / she seide to him in this wyse / Allas my lorde quod she / why make ȝe ȝoure self / for to be like a fool /
for sothe / it apparteneth nat to a wys man / to maken swich a sorwe /
ȝoure doughter / with the grace of god / shal warisshe and escape /
and al were it so / that she right now were ded / ȝe ne ought nat / as for hire deth / ȝoure self to destroye /
Senec¶ Seneca seith / the wyse man shal nat take to gret discomfort / for the deth of hise children /
but certes he shulde suffren it in pacience / as wel / as he abideth the deth / of his owene propre persone
¶ This Melibeus answered a-noon ⁊ seide / what man quod he shulde of his wepyng stynte / that hath so gret a cause for to wepe
¶ Ihesu Crist¶ Qualiter ihesus christus fleuit propter mortem laȝari oure lord / him self wepte / for the deth of laȝarus his frend.
Prudence answered / Certes wel I wot attempree wepyng is no thyng defended to him that sorweful is / amonges folk in sorwe / but it is rathere graunted him to wepe
¶ The Apostle Poule / vn-to the¶ Apostolus ad romanos Romayns wryteth / Man shal reioise / with hem that maken ioye / And wepen with swich folk as wepyn /
But though attempre wepyng / be I-graunted / outrageous wepyng / certes is defended /
Mesure of wepyng / shulde be considered / after the loore that techeth vs Senek /
whan that thy frend is ded quod he / lat nat thyne eyen to moiste ben of teeres / ne to meche drye / al-though the teeris / come to thyne eyen / lat hem nat falle;

And whan thow hast for-gon thy frend / do dili
gence / to gete a-geyn a-nother frend / and this is more wysdom / than for to wepe / for thy frend / which that þou hast lorn / for there-Inne is no bote /

And þerfore if ȝe gouerne ȝow by sapi
ence / put a-wey sorwe out of ȝoure herte.

¶ Remembre ȝow that Ihesus Syrak seith / a man that is ioyous in herte and glad / it him con
seruyth florisshyng in his age / but soothly . .
sorwe in herte sleeth ful many a man

¶ Sa
lamon seith / that right as moththes in the shepes flees / a-noyen to the clothes / and the smale wormes to the tree; right so anoyeth sorwe to the herte
¶ Wherfore vs oughte as wel in the deth of oure children / as in the losse of oure goodes temporeles / haue pacience.

¶ Remembre ȝow vp-on the pacient Iob / whan he hadde lost his children / and his temporel sub
staunce / and in his body endured and receyued ful many a greuous tribulacion / ȝet seide he thus /
Oure lord hath ȝeue it me / Oure lord hath biraft it me / right as oure lord hath wold / right so is it don / I-blissed be the name of oure lord

¶ To theise forseide thyngis answered Melibeus vn-to his wyf ¶ Prudence / Alle thyne wordes quod he ben sothe and þer-to pro
fitable / but trewely myn herte is troubled / with this sorwe so greuously / that I not what to done
¶ lat calle quod Prudence thyne trewe frendes alle / and thy lynage / which that ben wyse / telleth ȝoure caas / and herkeneth what they seye in counseillynge / and ȝow gouerne after here sentence
¶ Salamon seith: werke all thynges by counseille / and þou shalt neuere repente
¶ Thanne by the counseil of his wyf Prudence; this Melibeus / let callen a gret congregacion of folk /
as surgiens / Phisiciens / olde folk and ȝonge / and some of hise old enemyes reconsiled / as bi here semblaunt / to his loue / and in-to his grace /
and ther-with-al / ther comen somme of his neyghbores / that diden him reuerence / more for drede than for loue / as it happeth ofte
¶ Ther comen also ful many subtile flaterers and wyse aduocatȝ lerned in the lawe /
And whan this folk togydre assembled weren / This Melibeus in sorweful wyse / shewed hem his cas /

And by the manere of his speche / it semed that in herte he bar a crewel Ire / redy to don venge
aunce vp-oon his foos / ⁊ sodeynly desired / that the werre shulde bigynne /
but nathelees / ȝet axid he his counseil vp-oon this matere /
A surgien by licence and assent of swich as weren wyse / vp roos / and vn-to Melibeus / seide / as ȝe moun heere /
Sire quod he / as to vs Surgiens apparteneth / that we do to euery wyght the beste that we kan / where as we ben with-holde / and to our pacientȝ / that we do no damage /
wherfore it happeth many tyme and ofte / that whan twey men han euerych wounded other / O same surgien heleth hem bothe /
wherfore vn-to oure art / it is nat pertinent to norice werre / ne parties to supporte /

but certes as to the warisshynge of ȝoure doughter / al be it so / that she parllously be
wounded / we shuln do so ententyf besinesse / fro day to nyght / that with the grace of god / she shal be hool ⁊ sound / as sone as is possible
¶ Almost right in the same wyse the Phisiciens answerden / saue that they seiden a fewe wordes more /
that right as maladies ben cured / by here contraries / right so shal man warisshe werre / by vengeaunce

¶ hise Neygh
bores ful of Envie / hise feyned frendes / that semed reconsiled / hise flatereres
maden sembant of wepyng and empeired and aggregged mechel of this matere / in preisyng gretly Melibee / of myght / of power of richesse and of frendes / despisyng the power of hise aduersaries
and seiden outrely / that he a-noon / shulde wreke him on his foos / and bigynne werre
¶ vp ros thanne / an aduocat that was wys by leue and by counseil / of othere that were wyse / And seide /
lordynges the nede / for the which we ben assembled in this place / is ful heuy thyng / ⁊ an heigh matere
by cause of the wrong and of the wykkednesse that hath be doon / and eke by reson of the grete damages / that in tyme comynge ben possible to fallen / for the same cause /
and eke bi reson of the gret richesse and power of the parties bothe /
for the which resons / it were a ful gret perile to erren in this matere /

wherfore Melibeus / þis is oure sentence / we counseille ȝow a-bouen alle thyng / that riȝt a-noon þou do thy diligence in kepyng of thy propre persone / in swich a wyse / that þou ne wante noon espie ne wacche / thy body for to saue
¶ And after that we counseille / that in thyn hous thow sette suffisaunt garnyson / so that they moun / as wel thy body as thyn hous defende

¶ But certes for to meeue werre / ne sodeynly for to doon vengeaunce / we moun nat deme in so litel tyme / that it were profit
able /
wherfore we axen leiser and espace to haue deliberacion / in this cas to deme /
for the comune prouerbe seith this / he that sone demeth; soone shal repente /
And eke men seyn / that thilke Iuge is wys / that sone vnderstondeth a matere / and Iuggeth by leyser /
for al be it so / that al tariyng be a-noyful / algates it is nat to repreeue in ȝeuyng of Iugement ne in vengeaunce takyng / whan it is suffisaunt and resonable /

And that shewed oure lord Ihesu crist by en
sample / for whan that the womman that was taken in aduoutrie / was brought in his presence to knowen what shulde be don with hire persone / al be it / that he wist wel him self / what that he wolde answere / ȝet ne wolde he nat answere sodeynly / but he wolde haue deliberacion / And in the ground he wroot twies /
and by theise causes we axen deliberacion / and we shuln thanne by the grace of god / counseille the thyng / that shal be profitable

¶ vp stirte thanne / the ȝonge folk atones / and the most partie of that compaignye / han skorned þeise
olde wyse men / and bygonnen to make noyse / and seiden / that
right so / as whil that Iren is hoot / men shulde myte / right so men shuln do wreken here wronges / whils that they ben fresshe ⁊ newe / And with loude vois / they cryden / werre / werre /
vp roos tho / oon of theise olde wyse / ⁊ with his hond mad countenaunce / þat men shulde holde hem stille / ⁊ ȝeue him audience
¶ lordynges quod he / there is ful many a man that crieth werre / werre / þat wot ful litel what werre amounteth /
werre at his bigynnyng hath so gret an entryng / ⁊ so large / þat euery wight may entre whan him liketh ⁊ lightly fynde werre /
But certes to what ende / that shal þerof bifalle / it is nat light to knowe /
for sothly / whan þat werre / is ones bygonne / there is ful many a child vn-born of his moder that shul sterue ȝong / by cause of thilke werre / or elles lyue in sorwe / ⁊ dye in wrecchednesse /
And therfore / er that any werre be bigonne / men must haue gret counseil / ⁊ gret deliberacion /
⁊ whanne this olde man wende to enforce his tale by resouns / wel ny alle attones bigonne they to ryse / for to breken his tale / ⁊ beden him ful ofte / hise wordes for to a-bregge /
for sothly he that precheth to hem / that listen nat heren his wordes / his sarmoun hem anoyeth

¶ ffor Ihesus Syrak seith / That Musyk in wepyng / is a noyous thyng / This is to seyn / as muche auailleth to speken biforn folk / to which his speche a-noyeth / as it is to synge biforn him þat wepeth
¶ And whan this wys man sey / þat him wanted audience / Al shamefast / he sette him doun a-geyn /
for Salamon seith / þere as thow ne maist haue noon audience / enforce the nat to speke /
I se wel quod this wyse man / þat the comune prouerbe is soth / þat good counseil wanteth / whan it is most nede.
¶ Ȝet had this Melibeus in his counseil / many folk / that priuely in his Ere / counseilled him certeyn thyng / and counseilled him the contrarie in general audience.
¶ whan Melibeus had herd / that the grettest / partie of his counseil / were acorded / that he shulde make werre / a-noon he consented to here counseillynge / ⁊ fully affermed here sentence

¶ Thanne Dame Prudence / whan that she sey / how þat hire housbonde shop him / for to wreke him oon his foos / and to bigynne werre / she in ful humble wyse / whan she sey hire tyme / seide him theise wordes
¶ My lord quod she / I ȝow byseche / as hertily as I dar ⁊ kan / ne haste ȝow nat to faste / and for alle gerdouns / as ȝif me audience /
¶ ffor Piers Alfonse seith / who-so that doth to the outher good or harm / haste the nat to quyte it / for in this wyse / thy frend wol a-bide / ⁊ thyn enemy / shal the lengere lyue in drede
¶ The prouerbe seith he hasteth wel / that wysly kan a-byde / And in wykked hast / is no profyt /
This Melibe answered vn-to his wyf / Prudence / I purpose nat quod he / to werkyn by thy counseil / for many causes ⁊ resons / ffor certes euery wight / wold holde me thanne a fool /
this is to seyn; If I for thy counseillyng / wolde chaunge thynges / that
that had it biseged / and wolde it al destroye

¶ Abigail delyuerede Nabal hire housbonde fro Dauyd the kyng / that wolde han slayn him / ⁊ apaised the Ire of the kyng / by hire wyt / and by hire good coun
seillyng
¶ Hester by hire counseil / enhaunced gretly the peeple of god / in the regne / of Assureus the kyng /
And þe same bountee in good counseillyng / of many a good womman / moun men telle

¶ And more
ouer / whan that oure lord / had creat Adam oure forme fader / he seide in this wyse /
It is nat good / to be a man allone / make we to him an helpe / semblable to him self /
heere moun ȝe se / that if that wommen weren nat goode / ⁊ here counseil good ⁊ profitable /
oure lord god of heuene / wolde neither han wrought hem / ne called hem helpe of man / but rathere confusion of man /
⁊ there seide oones a Clerk in two vers what is bettre than gold; Iaspre / what is bettre than Iaspre; wysdom /
⁊ what is bettre than wysdom; womman / and what is bettre than good womman; no þing /
And sire / by manye of othere resons / moun ȝe sen / þat many wommen ben goode / ⁊ here counseil good ⁊ profitable
¶ And þerfore sire If ȝe wole troste to my counseil / I shal restore ȝow ȝoure doughter hool ⁊ sound /
⁊ I wol don to ȝow so muche / that ȝe shuln haue honoure in this cause.
¶ Whan Melibe had herd the wordes of his wyf Prudence / he seide thus /
I se wel / that the word of Salamon is soth / he seith þat wordes þat ben spoken discretly by ordynaunce / ben honycombes / for they ȝeuen swetnesse to the soule / ⁊ holsumnesse to the body /
And wyf / by cause of thyne swete wordes / ⁊ eke for I haue assaied / ⁊ preeued thy grete sapience / ⁊ thy gret trouthe / I wol gouerne me by thy counseil / in alle thyng
¶ Now sire quod Dame Prudence / ⁊ syn ȝe vouchesaf / to be gouerned by my counseil / I wol enforme ȝow / how ȝe shuln gouerne ȝoure self / in chesyng of ȝoure counseillours /
ȝe shuln first in alle ȝoure werkes / mekely byseken / to the heigh god / that he wol be ȝoure counseillour /
And shapeth ȝow to swich entente that he ȝeue ȝow counseil ⁊ comfort / as taughte Tobye his sone
At alle tymes / þou shalt blisse god / ⁊ preye him to dresse thyne weyes / ⁊ loke þat alle thyne counseils / ben in him for euere-moore //
¶ Seynt Iame eke seith / If any of ȝow haue nede of sapience axe it of god /
and afterward / thanne shuln ȝe take counseil / in ȝoure self/ and examyne wel ȝoure thoughtes / of swich thynges / as ȝow thynketh / that is best for ȝoure profyt /
And thanne shuln ȝe dryue fro ȝoure herte / thre thynges / þat ben contrarious to good counseil /
that is to seyn; Ire / Coueitise / ⁊ hastynesse
¶ ffirst he that axeth counseil of him self / certes he muste ben withouten Ire / for manye causes /

the firste is this / he þat hath gret Ire and wrathe in him self / he weneth alwey / þat he may do thyng / þat he
may nat do /
And secoundly / he that is Irous ⁊ wroth / he ne may nat wel deme /
And he that may nat wel deme / may nat wel counseille /
The thridde is this / that he þat is Irous ⁊ wroth / as seith Senek / ne may nat speke / but blameful thynges /
and with hise vicious wordes / he stereth oþere folk / to angre ⁊ to Ire
¶ And eke sire / ȝe muste dryue coueitise out of ȝoure herte /
for the Apostle seith / þat coueitise is the rote of alle harmes /
And trosteth wel / þat a coueitous man / ne kan nat deme / ne thenke / but oonly to fulfille the ende of his coueitise /
⁊ certes þat ne may neuere ben acomplised / ffor euere the more habundaunce þat he hath of richesse / the more he desireth
¶ And sire ȝe muste also dryue out of ȝoure herte / hastifnesse / for certes
ȝe ne moun nat deme for the beste / a sodeyn thouȝt / þat falleth in ȝoure herte / But ȝe muste avyse ȝow on it ful ofte /
for as ȝe herde here biforn / the comune prouerbe is this / that he þat sone demeth / sone repenteth /
Sire / ȝe ne be nat alwey / in like disposicion /
for certes som thyng / þat somtyme semeth to ȝow / þat it is good for to doo / A-nother tyme / it semeth to ȝow the contrarie /
whan ȝe han taken counseil vn-to ȝoure self / And han demed by good deliberacion / swich thyng as ȝow semeth best
¶ Thanne rede I ȝow / þat ȝe kepe it secree /
by-wreye nat ȝoure counseil to no persone / but if so be / þat ȝe wenen sikerly / þat thurgh ȝoure bywreiynge / ȝoure condicion shal ben to ȝow more profitable /
ffor Ihesus Syrak seith / Neyther to thy foo / ne to thy frend / diskeure nat thi secree / ne þi folie /
for they woln ȝeue ȝow audience ⁊ lokyng ⁊ supportacion in thy presence / ⁊ skorne the in thyn absence
¶ A-nother clerk seith / þat skarsly shalt þou fynden any persone / þat may kepe thy counseil secrely
¶ The book seith / whil þat þou kepest thy counseil in thyn herte / þou kepest it in thy prison /
And whan þou bewreyest thy counseil / to any wight / he holdeth the in his snare /
⁊ þerfore ȝow is bettre / to hide ȝoure counseil in ȝoure herte / than preye him to whom ȝe han by-wreyed ȝoure counseil / þat be wol kepe it clos ⁊ stille
¶ ffor Seneca seith / If so be /¶ Nota þat þou ne maist nat / thyn owen counseil hide / how darstow preyen / any oþer wight / thyn counseil secrely to kepe
¶ But nathelees / if þou wene sikerly / þat thy biwreiyng of þi counseil to a persone / wol make thy condicion / to stonden in the bettre pliȝt / thanne shalt þou telle him thy counseile in this wyse
¶ ffirst þou shalt make no semblaunt / wheiþer the were leuere pees or werre / or this / or that / ne shewe him nat thy wil / and thyn entente /
for troste wel / þat comunely theise counseillours ben flatereres /
namely the counseillours of grete lordes /
ffor they enforcen hem alwey / rather to speken plesaunte wordes / enclynyng to the lordes lust / than wordes / that ben trewe or profitable /

⁊ þerfore men seyn / þat þe riche man hath selde good coun
seil / but if he
haue it of him self /
And after þat / þou shalt considre þine frendes / ⁊ thyne enemys /

And as touchyng thy frendes / þou shalt con
sidre which of hem ben most feithful / ⁊ most wyse / ⁊ eldest ⁊ most appreued in counseillyng /
And of hem shalt þou axe thy counseil / as the cas requireth.

¶ I seye / þat first ȝe shuln clepe to ȝoure coun
seil / ȝoure frendes that ben trewe /
ffor Salamon seith / þat for right as the herte of a man / deliteth in sauour¶ Nota þat is swote / right so the counseil of trewe frendes / ȝeueth swetnesse to the soule //
he seith also / there may no thyng / be likned to þe trewe frend /
for certes / gold ne siluer ben nat so meche worth as the good wil / of a trewe frend //
And eke he seith / that a trewe frend / is a strong defence / who-so þat it fyndeth / certes he fyndeth a gret tresor
¶ Thanne shuln ȝe eke considre / if þat ȝoure trewe frendes / ben discrete ⁊ wyse / for the book seith / Axe alwey thy counseil of hem / þat ben wyse /
⁊ by this same reson / shuln ȝe clepen to ȝoure counseil of ȝoure frendes þat ben of age / swich as han seyn / ⁊ ben expert in manye thynges / ⁊ ben appreued in counseillynges
¶ ffor the book seith / in olde men is al the sapience / ⁊ in longe tyme the prudence

¶ And Tullyus seith / þat grete þinges ne ben ay acomplissed by strengthe / ne be delyuernesse of body / but by good counseil / by auctorite of persones ⁊ by science // The which thre thynges / ne ben nat fieble by age / but certes þei enforcen / ⁊ en
cresen day by day /
⁊ thanne shuln ȝe kepe this / for a general reule // ffirst ȝe shuln clepe to ȝoure counseil a fewe of ȝoure frendes þat ben especiale

¶ ffor Salamon seith / many frendes haue þou / but a-mong a thousand / chese the oon / to be thy counseil
lour /
for al it so be / þat þou first ne telle thy counseil / but to a fewe / þou maist afterward / telle it to moo folk / if it be nede /
but loke alwey / þat þine counseillours haue thilke thre condicions / þat I haue seid bifore / þat is to seye; þat they be trewe / wyse / ⁊ olde experience /
and werk nat alwey in euery nede / by oo counseillour allone / for somtyme bihoueth it to be counseiled by manye ///
ffor Salamon seith / Saluacion of thynges / is where as þere ben many counseillours.
¶ Now sithe þat I haue told ȝow / of which folk / ȝe shulde be counseilled / now wol I teche ȝow / which counseil ȝe oughte eschue

¶ ffirst ȝe shuln eschue / þe counseil of fooles ¶ ffor Salamon seith / take no coun
seil of a fool / for he ne can nat counseille / but after his owen lust / ⁊ his affeccion /
the book seith / the proprete of a fool / is this; he troweth lightly harm / of euery wight ⁊ lightly troweth al bounte / in him self

¶ Thow shalt eke eschue the counseillyng of alle flatereres / swich as enforcen hem / rathere to preysen ȝoure persone / by flaterye / than for to telle ȝow / the soth
fastnesse of thynges /.

¶ wherfore Tullyus seith / A-mong alle þe
pestilences þat ben in frendshipe / the grettest is flaterie / And þerfore it is more nede / þat þou eschue ⁊ drede flatereres / than any other peeple //
The book seith / þou shalt rathere / drede ⁊ flee / fro the swete wordes of flateryng preysers / than fro the egre wordes of thy frend / þat seith the thyne sothes
¶ Salamon seith / þat þe wordes of a flaterere / is a snare / to cacchen Innocenteȝ /
he seith also / þat he þat speketh to his frend / wordes of swetnesse / ⁊ of plesaunce / setteth a nette biforn his feet to cacchen him
¶ And þerfore seith Tullyus // Enclyne nat thyne Eres to flatereres / ne take no counseil / of wordes of flaterye
¶ and Caton seith ¶ Auyse the wel / þou shalt eschue / wordes of swetnesse ⁊ of plesance /
And eke þou shalt eschue the counseillyng of thyne olde enemys / that ben reconsiled
¶ The book seith / þat no wight retourneth safely / in-to the grace / of his old enemy
¶ And ysope seith / Ne¶ Nota trust nat to hem / to which þou hast had somtyme werre / or enemytee / ne telle hem nat thy counseil /
And Seneca telleth the cause why / It may nat be / seith he / þat where as gret fyr / hath longe tyme endured / þat þere ne dwelleth som vapour / of warmnesse //
And þerfore seith Salamon ¶ In þin olde ffoo / trost neuere /
for sikerly / though þin enemy be reconsiled / ⁊ makeþ þe chere of humilitee / ⁊ louteth to the with his hed / ne trost him neuere /

ffor certes / he maketh thilke feyned humilitee / more for his profyt / than for any loue of thy persone / by cause þat he dem
eth to haue victorie ouer þi persone / by swich feyned countenance / þe which victorie / he myght nat haue by strif of werre
¶ And Peter Alfonce seith / Make no felaweshipe with thyne olde enemys / for if þou do hem bounte / they wol peruerten it / in-to wykkednesse /
And eke þou must eschue / the counseillyng of hem / þat ben þine seruantȝ / ⁊ beren the gret reuerence / for parauenture they seyn it more for drede / þan for loue /
And þerfore seith a Philosophre in this wyse / There is no wyght parfytly trewe / to him / þat he sore dredeth
¶ and Tullius seith / þere nys no¶ Nota myght so gret of any Emperour / þat longe may endure / but if he haue more loue of the peeple / than drede
¶ þou shalt also eschue / þe counseillyng of folk þat ben dronkelewe / for they ne can / no counseil hide
¶ ffor Salamon seith / þere is no priuetee / ther as regneth dronkenesse
¶ ȝe shuln also han in suspect / þe counseillyng of swich folk / as counseille ȝow a thyng priuely / ⁊ counseille ȝow the contrarie openly
¶ ffor Cassidorie seith / þat it is a manere sleighte / to hyndree / whan he sheweth to don a thyng openly / ⁊ werk priuely the contrarie
¶ Thow shalt also haue in suspect / þe counseillyng of wykked folk / for here counseil is alwey / ful of fraude
¶ And Dauid seith / Blisful is þat man / þat hath nat folwed / the counseillyng of shrewes
¶ Thow shalt also eschue / the counseillyng of ȝonge folk / for here counseil is nat ripe.
¶ Now sire / sithe I haue shewed ȝow / of which folk / ȝe shullen folwe þe counseil
¶ Now wol I teche ȝow / how ȝe shuln examynen ȝoure counseil / after the doctrine of Tullius

¶ In the
examynynge thanne of ȝoure counseillour / ȝe shuln considre manye thynges

¶ Alderferst þou shalt considre / þat in thilke þing / þat þou purposest / ⁊ vp-oon what thyng / þou wolt haue counseil / þat verray trouthe be seid ⁊ conserued / this is to seyn; telle trewely thy tale /
ffor he þat seith fals / may nat wel be counseilled in þat cas / of which he lyeth

¶ And after this / þou shalt considre þe thynges / þat acorden to that þou purposest for to do / be thyne counseil
lours / if resoun acorde þer-to /
and eke if thy myght / may attenye þer-to / And if the more part / ⁊ the bettre part of þine counseillours / acorde þer-to or no //
Thanne shalt þou considre / what thyng shal folwe of þat counseillyng / as hate / pees / werre / grace / profyt / or damage / ⁊ manye oþere þinges
And in alle theise thynges / þou shalt chese the beste / And weyue alle othere thynges
¶ Thanne shaltow considere / of what roote is engendred / þe matere of thy counseil / ⁊ what fruyt it may conceyue ⁊ engendre
¶ Thow shalt eke considre / alle theise causes / from whennes they ben sprongen /
And whan ȝe haue examyned ȝoure counseil / as I haue seid / ⁊ which partie is the bettre / ⁊ more profitable And han appreued it / by manye wyse folk ⁊ olde /
than shaltow considere / if þou maist performe it / ⁊ maken of it a good ende /
ffor certes / resoun wol nat / þat any man shulde bygynne a thyng / but if he myghte performe it / as him oughte /
Ne no wight shulde take vp-oon him so heuy charge / þat he myght nat beren it
¶ ffor þe prouerbe seith; he þat to muche embraceth / distreyneth litel
¶ and Caton seith; Assay to do swich thyng / as þou hast power to don / lest þat the charge / oppresse the so sore / þat the byhoueth to weyue thyng / þat þou hast bygonne /
And if so be / þat þou be in doute / wheither þou maist performe a thyng or noo / ches rather to suffre / þan bigynne
¶ And Peter Alfonse seith; If þou hast myght to doon a thyng / of which þou must repente / it is bettre / nay / than ȝa /
this is to seyn; þat the is bettre to holde thy tonge stille / than for to speke
¶ Thanne moun ȝe vnderstonde / by strengere resons / þat if thow hast power to performe a werk / of which þou shalt repente / thanne is the bettre / þat þou suffre / þan bigynne /
wel seyn they / þat defenden euery wight / to assaye a thyng / of which he is in doute / wheiþer he may performe it / or no

¶ And after / whan ȝe han examyned ȝoure counseil / as I haue seid biforn / ⁊ knowen wel / þat ȝe moun per
forme ȝoure emprise / conferme it thanne sadly / til it be at an ende.

¶ Now is it reson ⁊ tyme / þat I shewe ȝow / whanne ⁊ wherfore / þat ȝe moun chaunge ȝoure counseil
lours / with-oute ȝoure repreue
¶ Sothly a man may chaunge his purpos / ⁊ his counseil if the cause ceseth / or whan a newe cas bitydeth /
for the lawe seith / vp-on thynges þat newely bityden / bihoueth newe counseil;
And Seneca seith; If thy counseil is comen / to the Eris of þin enemy / chaunge thy counseil

¶ Thow maist also chaunge thy counseil
if so be / þat þou fynde / þat by errour / or by other cause / harm or damage / may bitide /
Also if thy counseil be dishoneste / or elles cometh of dishoneste / cause / chaunge thy counseil /
ffor the lawes seyn / þat alle byhestes / þat ben dishoneste / ben of no value /
And eke if so be / þat it be inpossible / or may nat goodly be performed or kept /
And take this for a general reule ¶ That euery counseil / þat is affermed so strongly / þat it may nat be chaunged / for no condicion þat may betide I seye / þat thilke counseil is wykked.
¶ This Melibeus / whan he had herd the doctrine / of his wyf Dame Prudence / Answered in this wyse
¶ Dame quod he / as ȝet in-to this tyme / ȝe han wel ⁊ couenably taught me / as in general / how I shal gouerne me / in þe chesyng / ⁊ in the withholdyng of my counseillours /
But now wolde I fayn / þat ȝe wolde condescende in special /
⁊ telle me how liketh ȝow / or what semeth ȝow / by oure counseillours / þat we han chosen in our present nede.

¶ My lord quod she / I biseke ȝow in alle hum
blesse / þat ȝe wol nat wilfully / replie a-geyn my resons / ne distempre ȝoure herte / though I speke thyng / þat ȝow displese /
ffor god wot / þat as in myn entente / I speke it for ȝoure beste / for ȝoure honour / ⁊ for ȝoure profyte eke /

And sothly I hope / þat ȝoure be
nygnytee wil taken it in pacience
¶ Trusteth me wel quod she / þat ȝoure counseil as in this cas / ne shulde nat / as to speke proprely / be called a counseillyng / but a mocion or a meeuyng of folie /
in which counseil / ȝe han erred / in many a sondry wyse.

¶ ffirst ⁊ forward ȝe han erred in the assem
blyng / of ȝoure counseillours /
for ȝe shulde first / han cleped a fewe folk to ȝoure counseil / ⁊ after ȝe myghte han shewed it / to mo folk / if it hadde be nede /

But certes ȝe han sodeynly cleped to ȝoure coun
seil a gret multitude of peeple ful chargeant / ⁊ ful a-noyous for to heere

ne I am nat of the noumbre / of the right per

¶ Thanne thus / In getyng richesses / ȝe musten flee ydelnesse /

/ but I haue nat ȝet herd ȝour coun
seil / how I shal do in this nede
¶ Certes quod she / I counseile ȝow / þat ȝe acorde with ȝoure aduersaries / ⁊ þat ȝe haue pees with hem //
ffor seint Iame seith in hise Epistles; þat by concord and pees / þe smale richesses wexen grete /
⁊ by discord and debate / the grete richesses fallen doun
¶ And ȝe knowen wel / þat oon of the gretteste and moost souereyn thynges / þat is in this world / is vnyte and pees
¶ And þerefore seide oure lord Ihesu Crist to hise Apostlees / in this wyse /
wel happy ⁊ blissed be they / þat louen ⁊ purchasen pees / for they ben called / children of god
¶ A quod Melibee / now se I wel / þat ȝe louen nat myn honour / ne my worshipe
Ȝe knowen wel / þat myne aduersaries / han bigonne this debat ⁊ bryge / by here outrage
⁊ ȝe se wel / þat þei ne requeren / ne preye me nat of pees / ne they asken nat to be reconsiled /
wol ȝe thanne þat I go ⁊ meke me ⁊ obeye me to hem / ⁊ crie hem mercy;
ffor sothe þat were nat my worshipe /
ffor right as men seyn / þat ouer greet homlynesse / engendreth dispreisynge / so fareth it / by to greet humylitee / or mekenesse

¶ Thanne bygan Dame Prudence / to maken sem
blant of wratthe / ⁊ seide /
Certes sire / sauf ȝoure grace / I loue ȝoure honour / and ȝoure profit / as I do myn owene / ⁊ euere haue doon /
ne ȝe / ne noon other / seyn neuere the contrarie /
And if I had seid / þat ȝe shulde han purchased the pees / ⁊ the reconsiliacion / I ne hadde nat muchel mystake me / ne seid amys

¶ ffor the wyse man seith; The dis
sencion bigynneth by another man / and the reconsilynge bigynneth by thy self
¶ And the prophete seith; fflee shrewednesse / ⁊ do goodnesse /
seke pees ⁊ folwe it / as muchel as in the is
¶ Ȝet seie I nat / þat ȝe shuln rathere pursue to ȝoure aduersaries for pees / than they shuln to ȝow /
ffor I knowe wel / that ȝe ben so hard herted / þat ȝe wol do noo thyng for me
¶ And Salamon seith; þat he þat hath ouer hard an herte / atte laste / he shal myshappe ⁊ mystide //

whan Melibee had herd Dame Prudence / make semblaunt
of wrathe / he seide in thys wyse
¶ Dame I preye ȝow / þat ȝe be nat displesed / of thynges þat I seye /
for I knowe wel / þat I am angry ⁊ wrooth / ⁊ þat is no wonder /
⁊ they þat ben wrothe / witen nat wel / what they doon / ne what they seyn
¶ Therfore the prophete seith; troubled eyen / han noo cleer sighte;
But seith ⁊ counseileth me as ȝow liketh / for I am redy to doo / right as ȝe wol desire /
And if ȝe repreeue me of my folie / I am the more holden / to loue ȝow ⁊ to preise ȝow
¶ ffor Salamon seith; þat he that repreueth him / þat doth folie /
he shal fynde grettere grace / than he / þat deceyueth him by swete wordes
¶ Thanne seide Dame Prudence / I make no semblaunt of wrathe ne of angir / but for ȝoure grete profit

¶ ffor Salamon seith; he is more worth / þat re
preueth or chideth a fool for his folie / shewynge him semblaunt of wrathe /
than he þat supporteth him ⁊ preiseth him / in his mysdoynge ⁊ laugheth at his folie
¶ And this same Salamon seith; afterward; þat by the sorweful visage of a man / þat is to seyn; by the sory ⁊ heuy countenaunce of a man /
the fool correcteth ⁊ amendeth him self

¶ Thanne seide Melibee / I shal nat konne an
swere ȝow / vn-to so manye faire resons / as ȝe putten to me ⁊ shewen /

Seith shortly ȝoure wil and ȝoure coun
seil / and I am al redy / to fulfille ⁊ performe it /
Thanne Dame Prudence / discouered al hire wil to him / ⁊ seide /
I counseille ȝow quod she a-bouen alle thynges / þat ȝe make pees bitwene god ⁊ ȝow /
⁊ beth reconsiled vn-to him / ⁊ to his grace /
ffor as I haue seid ȝow heere biforn / god hath suffred ȝow / to haue this tribulacion ⁊ dissese for ȝoure synnes /
And if ȝe do as I seye ȝow / god wol sende ȝoure aduersaries vn-to ȝow /

⁊ make hem falle at ȝoure feet / redy to do ȝoure wyl ⁊ ȝoure com
aundementȝ

¶ ffor Salamon seith; whan the con
dicion of man / is plesaunt ⁊ likyng to god /

he chaungeth the hertes of the mannes aduersaries / ⁊ con
streyneth hem / to biseken him of pees ⁊ of grace /
I preye ȝow late me speke with ȝoure aduersaries in pryue place /
ffor they shuln nat knowe / þat it be of ȝoure wil / or ȝour assent /
And thanne / whan I knowe here wil ⁊ here entent / I may counseille ȝow / the moore seurly.
¶ Dame quod Melibe / doth ȝoure wil ⁊ ȝoure likynge /
for I putte me holly / in ȝoure disposicion and ordinaunce
¶ Thanne Dame Prudence / whan she sey / the good wil of hire housbonde / deliuered vn-to hire / ⁊ tok auysin hire self /
thynkynge how she myghte brynge this nede / vn-to good ende /
And whan she sey hire tyme / she sente for þeise aduersaries / to come vn-to hire in-to a pryue place /
⁊ shewed wysely vn-to hem the grete goodes þat comen of pees /

⁊ the gret harmes and
perils / þat ben in werre /

and seide to hem in goodly manere / how þat hem oughten haue gret re
pentaunce /
of the iniuries and wronges þat they hadden doon to Melibe hire lord / ⁊ vn-to hire ⁊ to hire doughter
¶ And whan they herden / the goodly wordes of Dame Prudence /
they weren so supprised and rauysshed ⁊ hadden so gret ioye of hire / þat wonder was to telle
¶ A lady quod they / ȝe han shewed vn-to vs / the blissynge of swetnesse / after the lawe of Dauid the prophete /
for the reconsilynge which we be nat worthy to haue / in no manere /
but we oughten requeren it / with gret contrition ⁊ humilitee /

ȝe of ȝoure grete goodnesse / haue presented vn
to vs

¶ Now se we wel / þat the science ⁊ the kon
nynge of Salamon is ful trewe /
ffor he seith / þat swete wordes multiplien ⁊ encressen frendes / and maken shrewes to be debonaire ⁊ meke
¶ Certes quod þei / we putten oure dede / and al oure matere ⁊ cause / al holly in ȝoure good wyl /

and ben redy to obeye / vn-to the speche / and comaunde
ment / of my lord Melibe /
And þerfore / deere ⁊ benygne lady / we preye ȝow ⁊ biseke ȝow / as mekely as we konne ⁊ moun /

that it like vn-to ȝoure gret goodnesse / to fulfille in dede ȝoure good
ly wordes /
ffor we consideren ⁊ knowelichen / þat we han offended / ⁊ greuyd my lord Melibe / out of mesure /
so ferforth / þat we ben nat of power / to maken his amendes /
And þerfore we oblige vs / ⁊ bynde vs ⁊ our frendes / for to do all his wil ⁊ hise comaundementȝ /
but perauenture / he hath swich heuynesse / ⁊ swich wrathe to vs-ward / by-cause of oure offence
þat he wol enioyne vs swich a peyne / as we moun nat bere / ne sustene /
And þerfore noble lady / we biseke / to ȝoure wommanly pitee /
to taken swich a-vysement in this nede / þat we ne oure frendes / ben nat desherited ⁊ destroyed thurgh oure folie
¶ Certes quod Prudence / it is an hard thyng and right perilous /
þat a man putte him al outrely in the arbitracion ⁊ Iuggement / ⁊ in the myght ⁊ powere of hise enemys //
ffor Salamon seith; leeueth me / ⁊ ȝeueth credence / to þat that I shal seyn / I seye quod he / ȝe peeple folk / ⁊ gouernours of holy chirche /
to thy sone / to thy wyf / to thy frend / ne to thy brother /
ne ȝeue þou neuere myght ne maistrie of þi body / whil þou lyuest
¶ Now sithen he defendeth / þat man shulde nat ȝeue / to his brother / ne to his frend / the myght of his body;
by a strengere reson / he deffendeth and forbedeth a man / to ȝeue him self to his enemy /

And nathe
lees I counseille ȝow / þat ȝe mystruste nat my lord /
ffor I woot wel ⁊ knowe verraily / þat he is debonaire ⁊ meke / large / Curteys /
⁊ no thyng desirous ne coueitous of good ne richesse /
For there nys no thyng in this world þat he desireth / saue oonly worshipe ⁊ honour
¶ fforþermore I knowe wel / ⁊ am right sure / þat he shal no thyng do in this nede / withouten my counseil /
and I shal so werken in this cause / þat by þe grace of oure lord god / ȝe shuln be reconsiled vn-to vs /
¶ Thanne seiden they with o vois; worshipful lady / we putten vs / and oure goodes / al fully in ȝoure wyl / ⁊ disposicion /
⁊ ben redy to come what day þat it lyke / vn-to ȝoure noblesse / to lymyte vs / or assigne vs
for to make oure obligacions and bond as strong as it liketh vn-to ȝoure goodnesse /
þat we moun fulfille the wyl of ȝow / ⁊ of my lord Melibe

¶ Whan Dame Prudence had herd the an
sweres of theise men she bad hem go a-geyn priuely /
and she retourned to hire lord Melibe / ⁊ told him how she fond hise aduersaries ful of repentaunt /
knowlechynge ful lowely here synnes ⁊ trespas / and how they weren redy to suffren al peyne /
requerynge ⁊ preiynge him / of mercy ⁊ pitee
¶ Thanne seide Melibe / he is wel worthy to haue pardoun ⁊ forȝefnesse of his synne / that excuseth nat his synne /
but knowlecheth ⁊ repenteth him / axynge indulgence //
¶ ffor Senek seith; there is the remission ⁊ forȝefnesse / where as the confession is /
ffor Confession is neyghbore to Innocence /
And þerfore I assente / and conferme me to haue pees /
but it is good / þat we do it nat with-outen thassent ⁊ wil / of oure frendes¶
Thanne was Prudence right glad ⁊ ioyeful / ⁊ seide /
Certes sire quod she / ȝe han wel ⁊ goodly answered;
ffor riȝt as by the counseil / assent ⁊ helpe of ȝoure frendes / ȝe han be stired to venge ȝow / and make werre /

Right so with
outen here counseil / shul ȝe nat a-corde ȝow / ne haue pees with ȝoure aduersaries /
ffor the lawe seith; þere nys no thyng so good / by weye of kynde / as a thyng to ben vnbounde / by him þat it was I-bounde
¶ And þanne Dame Prudence with-outen delay or tariynge / sent a-noon hire messageres for hire kyn and for hire olde frendes / which þat were trewe and wyse
⁊ told hem by ordre in the presence of Melibe / al this matere as it is a-boue expressed ⁊ declared /

⁊ preyed hem / þat they wolde ȝeue here auys ⁊ coun
seil / what were best to do in this nede

¶ And whan Melibeus frendes / hadden taken here auys ⁊ deliber
acion of the forseid matere /
⁊ hadden examyned it / by gret bysynesse ⁊ gret diligence;
they ȝouen ful counseil for to haue pees ⁊ reste
⁊ that Melibe shulde resseyue with good herte hise aduersaries / to forȝifnesse ⁊ mercy
¶ And whan Dame Prudence had herd the assent of hire lord Melibe ⁊ the counseil of hise frendes
acord / with hire wyl ⁊ hire entencion /
she was wonderly glad in hire herte / and seide /
There is an olde prouerbe quod she / seith; þat the goodnesse þat þou maist do this day / do it
and a-bide nat / ne delay it nat til to-morwe /
And þerfore I counseille / þat ȝe sende ȝoure messageres / swich as ben discrete ⁊ wyse /
vn-to ȝoure aduersaries / tellynge hem on ȝoure bihalue /
þat if they woln trete of pees ⁊ of a-cord /
þat they shape hem withouten delay or tariynge / to come vn-to vs /
which thyng perfourmed was in dede //
And whan theise trespassours ⁊ repentynge folk of here folies / þat is to seyn; the aduersaries of Melibe /
hadden herd what theise Messageres seiden vn-to hem /
they weren right glad ⁊ ioyeful / and answerden ful mekely ⁊ benygnely /
ȝeldynge graces and thankynges to here lord Melibe / ⁊ to al his compaignye
⁊ shopen hem withouten delay / to go with the Messagers ⁊ obeye / to the comaundement of here lord Melibe /
And right a-noon þei token here weye to the court of Melibe /
⁊ token with hem somme of here trewe frendes / to make feith for hem / and for to ben here borwes
¶ And whan they were come to the presence of Melibe / he seide hem theise wordes
¶ It stant thus quod Melibe / ⁊ sooth it is / that ȝe
causeles ⁊ withouten skyle ⁊ resoun /
han doon grete Iniuries ⁊ wronges to me and to my wyf Prudence / and to my doughter also /
for ȝe han entred in-to myn hous by violence /
and haue don swich outrage þat alle men knowen wel / that ȝe han deserued the deth /
⁊ þerfore wol I knowe ⁊ wite of ȝow /
wheither ȝe wol putte þe punysshynge ⁊ chastisynge / ⁊ the vengeaunce of this outrage in the wil of me ⁊ of my wyf / or ȝe wol nat.
¶ Thanne the wysest of hem thre / answered for hem alle / and seide / //
¶ Sire quod he / we knowen wel / þat we ben vnworthy / to come to the court of so gret a lord / ⁊ so worthy as ȝe ben /
ffor we han so gretly mystaken vs / ⁊ han offendid ⁊ a-gilt in swich a wyse ageyn ȝoure heye lordship /
þat trewely we han deserued the deeth /
But ȝet for the grete goodnesse ⁊ debonairetee / þat al the world wytnesseth of ȝoure persone /
we submitten vs to the excellence ⁊ benygnytee of ȝoure gracious lordshipe /
⁊ ben redy to obeye /to alle ȝoure comaundementes /
bysekynge ȝow / þat of ȝoure merciable pitee / ȝe wol considere oure grete repentaunce ⁊ lowe submission /
⁊ graunte vs forȝeuenesse of oure outrageous trespas ⁊ offence /

ffor wel we knowen / þat ȝoure liberal grace ⁊ mercy / strecchen hem for-þere in-to good
nesse / than doon oure outrageous giltes ⁊ trespas in-to wykkednesse /

al be it that cursedly ⁊ damp
nablely / we han a-gilt a-geyn ȝoure heye lordshipe
¶ Thanne Melibe tok hem vp fro the ground ful benygnely

⁊ receyued
here obligacions and here bondes / by here oothes vp-on here plegges ⁊ borwes /
and assigned hem a certeyn day / to retourne vn-to his court /
for to accept ⁊ receyue the sentence ⁊ Iugement / þat Melibe wolde comaunde to be doon on hem / by þe causes a-fore-seid /

which thynges or
deyned / euery man retourned to his hous.
¶ And whan þat dame Prudence saw hire tyme / she freyned ⁊ axed hire lord Melibe /
what vengeaunce he thoughte to taken of hise aduersaries
¶ To which / Melibe answered and seide ¶ Certes quod he / I thynke ⁊ purpose me fully /

to dis
herite hem / of al þat euere they han / ⁊ for to putte hem in exile for euere
¶ Certes quod Dame Prudence / this were a cruel sentence / and muchel a-geyn reson /
for ȝe ben riche I-now / and han no nede / of othere mennes good /
⁊ ȝe myght lightly in this wyse / gete ȝow a coueytous name /
which is a vicious þing ⁊ oughte ben eschewed of euery good man /
for after the sawe of the word of thapostle ¶ Coueytise is rote of alle harmes
and þerfore it were bettere for ȝow / to lese muchel good of ȝoure owene / than for to take of here good in this manere /

for bettere it is / to lese good with wor
ship / thanne it is / to wynne good with vyleynye ⁊ shame /

And euery man oughte to do his diligence ⁊ his bysy
nesse to gete him a good name /
⁊ ȝet shal he nat oonly / bisye him / in kepynge his good name /
but he shal also enforcen him alwey to do som thyng / by which he may renouelle his good name /

ffor it is wryten; þat þe olde good loos / or good name of a man / is sone goon ⁊ passed / whan it is nat newed / ne re
nouelled
¶ And as touchynge þat ȝe seyn / ȝe wol exile ȝoure aduersaries /
þat thynketh me muchel a-geyn reson / ⁊ out of mesure /

con
sidered the power þat they han ȝeuen ȝow / vp-oon hem self
¶ And it is wryten / þat he is worthy to leese his priuylege / þat mys-vseth the myght ⁊ the power / þat is ȝeue him
¶ And I sette cas / ȝe myghte enioyne hem þat peyne / by right ⁊ by lawe /
which I trowe ȝe mowe nat do /
I seye ȝe myghte nat putte it to execucion perauenture /
and thanne were it likly to retourne to the werre / as it was biforn /

and þerfore / if ȝe wole þat men do ȝow obeis
aunce / ȝe muste deme more curteisly /
this is to seyn; ȝe muste ȝeue more esy sentences ⁊ Iuggementȝ
¶ ffor it is wryten / þat he that most curteisly comaundeth / to him men muste obeyen

¶ And þer
fore I preye ȝow / þat in this necessitee ⁊ in this nede / ȝe caste ȝow to ouercome ȝoure herte
¶ ffor Senek seith; that he þat ouercometh his herte / ouercometh twyes /
And Tullius seith; þere is no thyng so comendable in a gret lord /

as whan he is debon
aire ⁊ meke / and appeiseth him
lightly /
And I preye ȝow / þat ȝe wol for-bere now / to do vengeaunce
in swich manere / þat ȝoure good name / may be kept and concerued /
And þat men moun haue cause ⁊ matere / to preise ȝow of pitee ⁊ of mercy
/ and that ȝe haue no cause / to repente ȝow of thyng þat ȝe doon
¶ ffor Senek seith; he ouercometh in al yuel manere/þat repenteth him nought of his victorie/

wher
fore¶ Nota I preye ȝow / lat mercy be in ȝoure herte /
to the effect ⁊ entente / that god al-myghty haue mercy on ȝow / in his laste Iuggement /

with
oute mercy shal be do to him / þat hath no mercy of a-nother wyght
¶ whan Melibe had herd / the grete skyles ⁊ resons of Dame Prudence / ⁊ hire wyse informacions and techynges /
his herte gan enclyne to the wyl of his wyf / considerynge hire trewe entente /

en
forced him a-noon ⁊ assented fully to werken after hire counseil /
⁊ thanked god / of whom procedeth al vertu / ⁊ al goodnesse / þat him sente a wyf / of so gret discrecion

¶ And whan the day cam / þat hise aduer
saries shulde appere in his presence /

he spak vn
to hem ful goodly / and seide in this wyse
¶ Al be it so / þat of ȝoure pride and hey presumpcion and folye / ⁊ of ȝoure neclygence / ⁊ vnkunnynge
ȝe haue mys-born ȝow / ⁊ trespaced vn-to me /
ȝet for as muchel / as I se ⁊ byholde ȝoure grete humylitee /
⁊ that ȝe ben sory ⁊ repentaunt of ȝoure giltes /
it constreyneth me / to do ȝow grace ⁊ mercy /
wherfore I receyue ȝow in-to my grace /
⁊ forȝeue ȝow outrely / alle the offences Iniuries and wronges þat ȝe haue doon a-geyn me ⁊ myne /
to this effect ⁊ to this ende / þat god of hise endeles mercy /
wole at the time of oure deyynge / for-ȝeue vs oure giltes / þat we han trespaced to him in this wrecched world /
for doutelees / if we be sory and repentaunt of the synnes ⁊ giltes which we han trespasced inne / in the sighte of oure lord god /

he is so free ⁊ so mercy
able /
þat he wole for-ȝeuen vs oure giltes /
and bryngen vs to the blisse / that neuere hath ende; Amen;
div.l: Here is ended Chaucers tale of Melibe;
⁊ bygynneth the Prologe of the Monkes tale;
WHan ended was my tale / of Melibe
And of Prudence / ⁊ hire benygnetee
Oure Host seide / as I am a feithful man
And by þat precious corpus / Madrian
I had leuere / than a barel ale
That goodleef my wyf / had herd this tale
She nys no-thyng / of swich pacience
As was this Melibeus wyf / Prudence
By goddes bones / whan I bete myne knaues
She bryngeth me / the grete clobbed staues
And cryeth / slee the dogges euerychon
And breke hem bothe bak / ⁊ euery bon
And if þat any neyghebore of myne
Wol nat in chirche / to my wyf enclyne
Or be so hardy / to hire to trespace
whan she cometh hom / she raumpeth in my face
And crieth fals coward / wreke thy wyf
By corpus bones / I wyl haue thy knyf
And þou shalt haue my distaf / ⁊ go spynne
Fro day to nyght / right thus she wol bigynne
Allas she seith / þat euere that I was shape
To wedde a mylk-soppe / or a coward ape
That wol ben ouer-ladde / with euery wyght
Thow darst nat stonde / by thy wyues right
This is my lif / but if that I wol fight
And out atte dore a-noon / I mot me dight
Or elles I am but lost / but if that I
Be like a wylde lyon / fool hardy
I wot wel / she wol do me slee / some day
Some neighebore / and thanne go my way
For I am perilous / with knyf in honde
Al be it / that I dar nat / hire withstonde
For she is bygge in armes / be my feith
That shal he fynde / þat hire mysdooth or seith
But late vs passe a-wey / fro this matere
My lord the Monk / quod he / be mery of chere
For ȝe shuln telle a tale / trewely
loo Rouchestre stant heere / fast by
Ride forth myn owne lord / breke nat our game
But by my trouthe / I knowe nat ȝoure name
wheiþer shal I calle ȝow / my lord Daun Iohn
Or Daun Thomas / or elles daun Albon
Of what hous be ȝe / by ȝoure fader kyn
I vow to god / þou hast a ful fair skyn
It is a gentil pasture / there þou goost
Thow art nat like a penaunt / or a goost
Vp-on my feith / þou art som officer
Som worthy Sexteyn / or som Celerer
For by my fadres soule / as to my dome
þou art a maister / whan þou art at home
No poore Cloistrer / ne no nowys
But a gouernour / wyly and wys
And there with al / of braunes ⁊ of bones
A wel faryng persone / for the nones
I preye to god / ȝeue him confusion
That first the brought / vn-to Religion
Thow woldest han ben / a tredfoul a-right
hadestow as gret a leue / as þou hast myght
To perfourme thy lust / in engendrure
Thow haddest bygeten / ful many a creature
Allas / why werest þou / so wyde a cope
God ȝeue me sorwe / but and I were Pope
Nat oonly þou / but euery myghty man
Though he were shore ful heye / vp-oon his pan
Shulde haue a wyf / for al the world is lorn
Religion hath take vp / al the corn
Of tredynge / ⁊ we borel men ben shrympes
Of feble trees / there come wrecched ympes
This maketh þat oure Eyres / ben so sklendre
And fieble / þat they moun nat wel engendre
This maketh þat oure wyues / woln assaie
Religious folk / for they moun bettre paie
Of Venus paiementȝ / than moun we
God wot / no lusshburgh / payen ȝe

loo this declaryng / ought I-now suffise

¶ Cenobia / of Palymerie Quene¶ Cenobia
As wryten Persiens / in here noblesse
So worthy was in armes / ⁊ so kene
That no wight passed hire / in hardynesse

¶ ffrom hire childhode / I fynde þat she fledde

¶ She durste / wilde Bestes dennes / seke

Ageyns this hest / no wyght dar trespace

where Eliachym / a Preest was / of þat place
¶ But take kepe of the deth / of Oliferne
A-mydde his oost / he dronke lay a nyght
with-Inne his tent / large as is a berne
And ȝet for al his pompe / ⁊ al his myght
Iudith a womman / as he lay vp-right
Slepynge / his hed of smote / ⁊ from his tente
Ful pryuyly she stal / from euery wyght
And with his hed / vn-to hire toun she wente
¶ what nedeth it / of king Anthiocus¶ De Anthioco illustri
To telle / his heygh / real mageste
his heigh pride / his werkes venimus
For swich a-nother was þere noon / as he
Rede which that he was / in Machabe
And rede the proude / that he seide
And why he fel / fro heigh prosperite
And in an hil / how wrecchedly he deyde
¶ ffortune him hadde / enhaunced so in pride
That verreyly / he wende he myghte atteyne
Vn-to the sterres / vp-on euery syde
And in balaunce weyghen / ech mounteigne
And alle the floodes / of the see / restreyne
And goddes peeple / had he moost in hate
Hem wolde he sleen / in turment and in peyne
wenyng þat god ne myghte / his pride abate
¶ And for þat Nichanor / and Thimothe
with Iewes were / venquysshed myghtily
Vn-to the Iewes / swich an hate had he
That he bad / Greithe his Char / ful hastily
And swor and seide / ful dispitously
Vn-to Ierusalem / he wolde eft sone
To wreke his Ire on hit / ful crewelly
But of his purpos / he was lette ful sone
¶ God for his manace / him so sore smote
With invisible wounde / ay incurable
That in hise guttes / karf it so ⁊ bote
That hise peynes / weren inportable
And certeynly the wrecche / was vnresonnable
For many a mannes guttes / did he peyne
But from his purpos cursed / and dampnable
For al his smert / he wolde him nat restreyne
¶ But bad a-noon / apparailen his oost
And sodeynly / or he was of it war
God daunted al his pride / and al his boost
For he sore fil / out of his Char
That it hise lymes / ⁊ his skin to-tar.id est lacerauit.
So þat he neither / myght go ne ryde
But in a Char / men a-boute him bar
Al forbrused / bothe bak and syde
¶ The wreche of god / him smote so cruelly
That thurgh his body / wykked wormes crepte
And ther with al / he stank so horribly
That noone of alle his meyne / þat him kepte
Wheither so he woke / or elles slepte
Ne myght nought the stynk / of him / endure
In this myschief / he wayled and eke wepte
And knew god / lord / of euery creature
¶ To al his oost / ⁊ to him self also
Ful wlatsom was the stynk / of his careyne
No man ne myght him bere / to ne froo
And in this stynk / ⁊ this orrible peyne
he starf ful wrecchedly / in a Mounteigne
Thus hath this robbour / ⁊ this homycide
That many a man / made / to wepe ⁊ pleyne
Swich gerdoun / as bilongeth vn-to pride
¶ The storie of Alexandre / is so comune¶ De Alex|andro.
That euery wyght / þat hath discrecion
hath herd somwhat / or al / of his fortune
This wyde world / as in conclusion
he wan by strengthe / or for his heigh renoun
They were glad / for pees / vn-to him sende
The pride of man and beest / he leide a-doun
where so he come / vn-to the worldles ende
¶ Comparison / myght neuere ȝet be maked
Bitwix him / and another Conquerour
For al this world / for drede of him hath quaked
he of knyghthode / and of fredome flour
Fortune him maked / the Eyr of hire honour
Saue wyn ⁊ wommen / no thyng myght a-swage
his heigh entent / in armes and labour
So was he ful / of leonyn corage
¶ what prys were it to him / though I ȝow tolde
Of Darius / and an hundred thousand moo
Of kynges / Princes / Dukes / Erles bolde
which he conquered / ⁊ brought hem in-to woo
I seye / as fer / as man may ride or go
The world was his / what shulde I more deuyse
For though I wryte / or told ȝow euere moo
Of his knyghthode / it might nat suffise
¶ xij ȝer he regned / as seith Machabe
Philippus sone / of Macedoyne he was
That first was kyng / in Grece / the Contre
O worthy gentil Alisandre / allas
That euere shulde fallen / swich a kas
Empoysenned / of thyne owen folk / þou were
thy Sys fortune / hath turned in-to as
And for the / ne wep she neuere / a teere
¶ who shal me ȝeue teres / to compleyne
The deth of gentillesse / ⁊ of fraunchise
That al this world welded / in his demeyne
And ȝet him thoughte / it myghte nat suffise
So ful was his corage / of hey emprise
Allas who shal me helpe / to endyte
False fortune / ⁊ poyson to despise
The which two / of al this woo / I wyte
¶ By wysdom / manhed / and by gret labour¶ De Iulio Cesare
Fram humble bedde / to real magestee
vp ros he / Iulius / the Conquerour
That wan al thoccident / by lond and see
By strengthe of hond / or elles by tretee
And vn-to Rome / made hem tributarie
And sithe of Rome / the Emperour was he
Til þat fortune / wex his aduersarie
¶ O myghty Cesar / that in Thessalie
Ageyns Pompeus / fader thyn in lawe
That of the Orient / had al the Chyualrie
As fer as þat the day / bigynneth dawe
Thow thurgh thy knyghthode / hast hem take ⁊ slawe
Saue fewe folk / that with Pompeus fledde
Thurgh which þou puttest / al thorient in awe
Thanke fortune / that so wel the spedde
¶ But now a litel while / I wyl bywayle
This Pompeus / this noble gouernour
Of Rome / which þat fley at this bataille
I seye / oon of his men / a fals traitour
his hed of smot / to wynnen him fauour
Of Iulius / and him the hed he brought
Allas Pompeie / of thorient Conquerour
That fortune / vn-to swich a fyn / the brought
¶ To Rome a-geyn / repaireth Iulius
with his triumphe / lauriat ful heye
But on a tyme / Brutus Cassius
That euere hadde / of his hey estat / envye
Ful priuyly / hath made / Conspiracie
Ageyns this Iulius / in sotile wyse
And cast the place / in which he shulde deye
with boydekyns / as I shal ȝow deuyse
¶ This Iulius / to the capitolie wente
vp-on a day / as he was wont to gon
And in the Capitolie / a-noon him hente
This false Brutus / ⁊ hise othere foon
And stryked him / with Boydekyns / a-noon
with many a wounde / ⁊ thus they lete him lye
But neuere grunt he / at no stroke / but oon
Or elles at two / but if his storie lye
¶ So manly was this Iulius / of herte
And so wel loued / estatly honeste
That though hise dedly woundes / so sore smerte
his mantel ouer hise hipes / caste he
For no man shulde sen / his pryuete
And as he lay of deyinge / in a traunce
And wist verreily / that ded was he
Of honeste / ȝat had he / remembraunce
¶ Lucan to the / this storie I recomende
And to Sweton / and to valerius also
That of the storie / wryten word and ende
how þat theise grete / Conquerours two
Fortune was first frend / and sithe a foo
No man ne truste / vp-oon hire fauour longe
But haue hire in a-wayte / for euer mo
wytnesse on alle / theise Conquerours stronge
¶ This riche Cresus / whilom kyng of lyde¶ Cresus
Of whiche / Cresus Cirus / sore him drawe
Ȝet was he kaught / a-myddes al his pride
And to be brent / men to the fyr him ladde
But such a reyn / down fro the walken shadde
That it slow the fyr / ⁊ made to him escape
But to be war / no grace ȝet he hadde
Til fortune / on the galwes / made him gape
¶ Whan he eskaped was / he gan nat stynte
For to begynne / a newe werre a-geyn
he wende wel / for þat fortune him sente
Swich hap / þat he eskaped thurgh the reyn
That of his foos / he myghte nat be slayn
And eke a sweuene / vp-oon a nyght he mette
Of which he was so proud / ⁊ eke so fayn
That in vengeaunce / he al his herte sette
¶ Vp-oon a tree he was / as þat him thoughte
where Iupiter him wessh / bothe bak ⁊ syde
And Phebus eke / a fair towayl him broughte
To drye him with / ⁊ her-for wex his pride
And to his doughter / þat stod him beside
which þat he knew / in hey science habounde
he bad hire telle him / what it signyfiede
And she his drem / bygan right thus expounde
¶ The tree quod she / the galwes is to mene
And Iuppiter bitokeneth / Snow ⁊ reyn
And Phebus / with his towayle so clene
Tho ben the Sonnes stremes / for to seyne
Thow shalt an-hanged be / fader certeyne
Reyn shal the wasshe / ⁊ sonne shal the drye
Thus warned him ful plat / ⁊ ful pleyne
his doughter / which þat called was / Phanye
¶ An-hanged was Cresus / the proude kyng
His real trone / myght him nought a-vaille
Tragedi es / noon other maner thyng
Ne can in syngynge / crie ne bywaille
But for þat fortune / alday wol assaille
with vnwar strok / the Regnes þat ben proude
For whan men trosten hire / than wyl she faille
And keuere hire bright face / with a cloude
¶ O noble / o worthy Petre / glorie of spayne¶ Petro
whom fortune helde / so heigh in mageste
wel oughten men / thy pytous deth compleyne
Out of thy lond / thy brother mad the flee
And after at a Sege / by sotiltee
where as he / with his owen hand slow the
Succedyng in thy regne / ⁊ in thy rente
¶ The felde of snow / with the Egle of blak þere-Inne
kaught with the lyme rod / coloured as the glede
he breweth this cursednesse / ⁊ al this synne
The wykked nest / was wirker of this nede
Nought Charles / Olyuer / þat toke ay hede
Of trouthe ⁊ honour / but of Armorike
Genylon / Olyuer / corrupt for mede
Brought this worthy knyght / in swich a brike
¶ O worthy Petro / kyng of Cipre also¶ Petro
That Alisaundre wan / by heigh maistrie
Ful many an hethen / wroughtestow ful woo
Of which thyne owne lieges / hadden envye
And for no thyng / but for thy Chyualrie
They in thy bed / han slayn the by the morwe
Thus kan fortune / hire whel gouerne ⁊ gye
And out of ioye / brynge men to sorwe
¶ Of Melan / gret Barnabo / viscounte¶ Barnabo
God of delit / and skourge of lumbardie
Why shulde I nought / thyn Infortune Acompte
Sithe in estat / þou clombe were so heighe
Thy brothers sone / þat was thy double allye
For he thy nevew was / ⁊ sone in lawe
with-Inne his prison / made the to dye
But why / ne how not I / þat þou were slawe
¶ Of the Erl Hugelyn / of Piȝe the langour¶ Hugelyn
There may no tonge tellen / for pitee
But litel out of Piȝe / stant a Tour
In which Tour / in prison put was he
And with him ben / hise litel children three
The eldest skarsely / fyue ȝer was of age
Allas fortune / it was gret crueltee
swich Briddes / for to putte / in swich a cage
¶ Dampned was he / to dye in þat prison
For Roger / which þat Busshop was / of Piȝe
had on him mad / a fals suggestion
Thurgh which the peeple / gan vp-oon him rise
And putten him to prison / in swich wyse
As ȝe han herd / ⁊ mete ⁊ drynk he hadde
So smal / that wel vnethe / it may suffise
And ther-with-al / it was ful poore ⁊ badde
¶ And oon a day bifel / that in that houre
whan þat his mete / wont was to be brought
The Gayler shette the dores / of the Tour
he herd it wel / but he spak right nought
And in his herte / a-noon þere fel a thought
That they for honger / wolde don him dyen
Allas quod he / allas þat I was wrought
There-with the teres / fellen from hise eyen
¶ his ȝonge sone / þat thre ȝer was of age
vn-to him seide / fader / fader / why do ȝe wepe
whan wyl the gailler / bryngen oure potage
Is þere no mussel bred / that ȝe do kepe
I am so hungry / that I may nat slepe
Now wolde god / þat I myght slepen euere
Thanne shulde nought hunger / in my wombe crepe
There is no thyng but bred / þat me were leuere
¶ Thus day by day / this child bygan to crie
Til in his his fadres barm / a-doun it lay
And seide / fare wel fader / I mot dye
And kist his fader / ⁊ dyed the same day
And whan the wooful fader / ded it say
For woo / hise armes two / he gan to byte
And seide allas fortune / and weylaway
Thy false whel / my woo al may I wyte
¶ Hise children wend / þat it for hunger was
That he hise armes gnow / ⁊ nat for woo
And seiden fader / do nat so allas
But rathere ete the flessh / vp-oon vs two
Oure flessh þou ȝaf vs / take oure flessh vs froo
And ete I-now / right thus / þei to him seide
And after þat / with-Inne a day or two
The leide hem in his lappe a-doun / ⁊ deide
¶ him-self dispeired eke / for hunger starf
Thus ended is / this myghty Erl of Pise
From heigh estat / fortune a-way him karf
Of this tragedye / it ought I-now suffise
who so wol heere it / in a lengere wyse
Redeth the grete Poete / of ytaille
That hight Daunt / for he can it al deuyse
Fro poynt to poynt / nat oo word wil he faille
¶ Here endeth the Monkes Tale / de casibus virorum Illustrium
Here bigynneth the Prologe of the Nonnes Prest /
HOo quod the knyght / good sire no more of this
That ȝe han seid / is right I-now I-wys
And mochel more / for litel heuynesse
Is right I-now / for mechil folk I gesse
I seye for me / it is a gret dissese
where as men han ben / in gret welthe ⁊ ese
To heren of here sodeyn fal / allas
And the contrarie is ioye / ⁊ gret solas
As whan a man hath ben / in poure estat
And clymbeth vp / and wexeth fortunat
And there abydeth / in prosperitee
Swich thyng is gladsom / as it thynketh me
And of swich thyng / were goodly for to telle
ȝa quod oure hoost / by seynt Poules belle
ȝe seye right soth / this Monke he clappeth loude
he spak how fortune / couered was with a cloude
I not neuere what / and als of a tragedie
Right now ȝe herde / and parde no remedie
Is it / for to be-wayllen / ne compleyne
Thatid quod þat is don / and als it is a peyne
As ȝe han seide / to heere of heuynesse
Sire Monke no more of this / so god ȝow blisse
Ȝoure tale a-noyeth / al this compaignye
Swich thyng is nat worth / a boterflye
For þere-Inne is ther/ no disporte ne game
wherfore sire Monke / o daun Piers by thy name
I preye ȝow hertily / telle vs som-what elles
For sikerly / nere clynkyng of ȝoure belles
That oon ȝoure bridel hange / oon euery syde
By heuene kyng / þat for vs alle dyde
I shulde er this / haue fallen doun for slepe
Al-though the slough / had neuere ben so depe
Thanne had ȝoure tale / al ben tolde in veyn
For certeynly / as þat theise Clerkes seyn
where as a man / may haue noon audience
Nat helpeth it / to tellen his sentence
And wel I woot / the substaunce is in me
If any thyng / shal wel reported be
Sire seye somwhat / of huntyng I ȝow preye
¶ Nay quod this Monke / I haue no lust to pleye
Now lat a-nother telle / as I haue tolde
Thanne spak oure hoost / with rude speche ⁊ bolde
And seide vn-to the Nonnes preest / a-noon
what eyleth ȝow to grone / in this manere
ȝe ben a verrey slepere / fy for shame
And he answerde / and seide thus / Madame
I preye ȝow / that ȝe take it nat a grief
By god me mette / I was in swich meschief
Right now / þat ȝet myn herte / is sore a-fright
Now god quod he / my sweuene recche a-right
And kepe my body / out of foule prisoun
¶ Me mette how that I romed / vp and doun¶ Dreem
with-Inne oure ȝerd / where as I saugh a beest
was lyke an Hound / ⁊ wolde han mad a-reest
vp-on my body / and an had me deed
his colour was bitwexe / ȝelew and reed
And tipped was his tail / ⁊ bothe hise Erys
with blak / vnlike the remenaunt of hise heris
his snoute was smal / with glowyng eyen tweye
Ȝet for his look / for fere al-moost I deye
This caused me / my gronyng doutelees
¶ A voy quod she / fy oon ȝow hertelees
Allas quod she / for by þat god a-boue
Now han ȝe loost myn herte / ⁊ al my loue
I can nought loue a Coward / by my feith
For certes / what so any womman seith
we alle desyren / if it myght be
To han an housbonde / hardy wys ⁊ free
And secree / ⁊ no nygard / ne no fool
Ne him þat is a-gast / of euery tool
Ne noon auentour / by þat god a-boue
how dursten ȝe for shame / seye to ȝoure loue
That any thyng / myght make ȝow a-ferd
han ȝe no mannes herte / and han a berd
Allas / and konne ȝe ben a-gast of sweuenys
No thyng god wot / but vanytee in sweuene is
Sweuenes ben engendred / of replexiouns
And ofte of fume / and of complexiouns
Whan humours ben to habundaunt / in a wyght
Certes this drem / which ȝe han met to-nyght
Cometh of the gret / superfluytee
Of ȝoure rede Colera / parde
which causeth folk / to dredyn in here dreemes
Of arwes and of fyr / with rede lemes
Of rede beestes / that they wol hem byte
Of contekes and of waspes / grete and lyte
Right as the humour / of malencolie
Causeth many a man / in sleep to crie
For fere of Blake Beres / or Booles blake
Or elles blake deueles / þat wole hem take
Of othere humours / coude I telle also
That werken many a man / is sleep ful woo
But I wol passe / as lightly as I can
lo Caton which / þat was so wys a man
Seide ne nat thus / ne do no fors of dremes
Now sire quod she / whan we flee fro theise bemes
For goddes loue / as take som laxatyf
vp peril of my soule / and of my lyf
I counseil ȝow the beste / I wol nat lye
That bothe of colour / and of malencolie
ȝe purge ȝow / and for ȝe shuln nat tarie
Though in this toun / is noon Appotocarie
I shal my self / to herbes techen ȝow
That shal be for ȝoure ese / ⁊ for ȝoure prow
And in oure ȝerd / the Erbes shal I fynde
The which han / of here proprete / by kynde
To purgen ȝow bynethe / and eke a-boue
Sire forȝete nat this / for goddes loue
ȝe ben ful colerik / of complexioun
war that the sonne / in his assencioun
Ne fynde ȝow nat / replet / of humours hote
And if it do / I dar wel leye a grote
That ȝe shuln han / a feuere terciane
Or an agu / which þat may be ȝoure bane
A day or two / ȝe shuln han degestyues
Of wormes / or ȝe take ȝoure laxatyues
Of lauriol / centaure / and fumetere
Or elles of ellebor / that groweth there
Of Catapuce / or of gait-Rys beries
Of herbe yue / growyng in oure ȝerd / þere merie is
Pikke hem right as they growe / and ete hem In
Beth merie housbonde / for ȝoure fader kyn
Dredeth no dreem / I can sey ȝow no more
¶ Madame quod he / graund mercy of ȝoure lore
But nathelees / as touchyng daun Catoun
That hath of wysdom / swich a gret renoun
Though þat he bad / no dremes for to drede
By god men moun / in olde bookes rede
Of many a man / more of auctoritee
Than euere Catoun / was / so moot I the
That al the reuers seyn / of his sentence
And han wel founden / by experience
That dremes ben / significaciouns
As wel of ioye / as tribulaciouns
That folk enduren / in this lyf present
There nedeth make of this / noon argument
The verray preeue / sheweth it in dede
Oon of the grettest auctour / that men rede¶ Tullius
Seith thus / þat whilom tweye felawes wente
On pilgrimage / in a ful good entente
And happed so / þat they cam in a toun
where there was swich / a congregacioun
Of peeple / and eke so streyt / of herbergage
That they ne founde / as moche as a cotage
In which they myght / I-logged be
wherfore they musten / of necessite
As for þat nyght / departen compaignye
And ech of hem gooth / to his hostelrie
And took his loggynge / as it wolde falle
That oon of hem was logged / in a stalle
Fer in a ȝerd / with Oxen of the plow
That oþer man was logged / wel y-now
As was his auenture / or his fortune
That vs gouerneth / as in comune
¶ And so bifel / þat longe or it was day
This man mette in his bed / þere as he lay
how þat his felawe / gan vp-oon him calle
And seide allas / for in an Oxes stalle
This nyght I shal be mordred / þere I lye
Nowe helpe me dere brother / or I dye
In alle haste / come to me he seyde
This man out of his sleep / for fere abreyde
But whan þat he was wakned / of his sleep
he turned him / ⁊ took of this no keep
him thought his dreem / nas but a vanytee
Thus twyes in his sleep / dremed he
And at the thridde tyme / ȝet his felawe
Cam as him þought / ⁊ seide / I am now slawe
Byholde my bloody woundes / depe ⁊ wyde
Arys vp erly / in the morwe tyde
And at the west gate / of the Toun quod he
A carte ful of donge / þere shalt þou se
In which my body is hid / ful preuyly
Do thilke carte aresten / boldly
My gold caused my mordre / soth to seyn
And told him euery poynt / how he was slayn
with a ful pytous face / pale of hewe
And trosteth wel / this dreem he fond ful trewe
For oon the morwe / as sone as it was day
To his felawes In / he took his way
And whan þat he cam / to this Oxes stalle
After his felawe / he bygan to calle
The hostiler answered him / a-noon
And seide sire / ȝoure felawe is a-gon
As sone as day / he went out of the Toun
This man gan fallen / in suspeccioun
Remembryng on hise dreemes / þat he mette
And forth he gooth / no lengere wold he lette
vn-to the west gate of the toun / and fond
A dong cart / went for to donge lond
That was arrayed / in the same wyse
As ȝe han herd / the dede man deuyse
And with an hardy herte / he gan to crie
vengiaunce and iustice / of this felonye
My felawe murdred is / this same nyght
And in this Carte he lith / gapyng vp-right
I crie out on the Ministres / quod he
That shulden kepe ⁊ reule / this Citee
Harrow allas / heere lith my felawe slayn
what shulde I more / vn-to this tale seyn
The peeple out stirte / ⁊ cast the cart to grounde
And in the myddel of the donge / they founde
The dede man / þat murdrid was al newe
¶ O blisful god / þat art so iust and trewe
loo how þat þou bywreyest / murdre alway
Murdre wol out / that se we day by day
Murdre is so wlatsom / ⁊ abhomynable
To god / that it so iust and resonable
That he ne wol nat suffre it / heled be
Though it abyde / a ȝer or two or three
Murdre wol out / this is my conclusioun
And right a-noon / Mynistres of the toun
hant hent the Carter / and so sore him pyned
And eke the Hosteler / so sore engyned

¶ Cecile / may eke be seid / in this manere
wantyng of blyndnesse / for hire grete light
Of sapience / and for hire thewes clere
Or ellis lo / this maydenes name bright
Of heuene and leos / cometh / for which by right
Men myghte hire wel / the heuene of peeple calle
Ensample of good / and wyse werkes alle
¶ ffor leos peeple / in englissh is to seye
And right as men moun / in the heuene se
The Sonne ⁊ Moone / and sterres euery weye
Right so / men goostly / in this mayden free
Seyen of feith / the magnanymytee
And eke the clernesse / hol of sapience
And sondry werkes / brighte of excellence
¶ And right so / as theise philosophres wryte
That heuene is swift / ⁊ round / ⁊ eke brennynge
Right so was faire Cecile / the white
Ful swift ⁊ bysy / euere in good werkynge
And round and hool / in good perseuerynge
And brennyng euere / in Charite ful brighte
Now haue I ȝow declared / what she highte
